definition: to angle for fame (idiom)/to fish for compliments
abbr. for Tianjin 天津 (also 津沽)
to buy/to sell
name/noun (part of speech)/place (e.g. among winners)/famous/classifier for people
to fish with a hook and bait
to praise/to acclaim/reputation

sentences.english: Many people value fame and seek fame.
Some say the fish for fame, not long dry on the steering political springboard.
sentences.chinese: 也有人說是沽名釣譽，幹不長時間就轉向政治跳板。

sentences.english: Nothing is more detestable than the man who courts popularity.
sentences.chinese: 再沒有比沽名釣譽的人更令人厭惡了。

sentences.english: He wants no members in his political party who are just along for the ride.
sentences.chinese: 他不要任何沽名釣譽，搭順風車的人在他的政黨裏。

sentences.english: She is always fishing for compliments.
He never trusted fame, and always boxed up and guarded his ego.
sentences.chinese: 他從不沽名釣譽，而是保持距離，忠於自我。

sentences.english: Those who fish for fame and honors will end up nowhere.
sentences.chinese: 沽名釣譽的人最後將一事無成。

sentences.english: Generally to say, is enthusiastic pursuit of the world in general.
sentences.chinese: 總括地說，世人一般所熱心的是沽名釣譽。

definition: scramble for power and profit (idiom); power struggle
public enemy
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
see 拔苗助長|拔苗助长[ba2 miao2 zhu4 zhang3]
running of armed forces/military management/to govern armed forces/to direct troops
to be chivalrous
idle gossip
to make an irrelevant comparison or interpretation (idiom)
video program
exclusive property/forbidden domain
to shoot without aim (idiom); fig. to speak without thinking/firing blindly/to shoot in the air/a shot in the dark
henchmen
fight a battle of words/cross verbal swords
scoundrel/rogue/bully/villain
code of conduct/standard of conduct
equestrianism/horsemanship
